questions.text: Which drug is most likely responsible for the occurrence of hyperthermia and muscle rigidity in a patient undergoing surgery while being administered anesthesia with halothane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of halothane anesthesia with suxamethonium (succinylcholine) can precipitate malignant hyperthermia (MH) in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • MH is a life-threatening pharmacogenetic disorder characterized by:
    • Hyperthermia
    • Generalized muscle rigidity
    • Hypercapnia (increased CO2)
    • Tachycardia and metabolic acidosis
  • The underlying mechanism is uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle due to abnormal ryanodine receptors, leading to sustained muscle contraction and heat production.
  • Immediate treatment is with IV dantrolene, which inhibits calcium release, along with supportive measures like cooling and correcting metabolic derangements.

Malignant Hyperthermia:

  • Triggers: Volatile anesthetics (halothane, sevoflurane, isoflurane, desflurane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine).
  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant inheritance, commonly involving mutations in the RYR1 gene.
  • Complications: Rhabdomyolysis, arrhythmias, renal failure, and death if untreated.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

D-curare (Option A): A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It does not trigger malignant hyperthermia.

Cis-atracurium (Option C): A non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, known for organ-independent metabolism (Hofmann elimination). It is safe and not associated with MH.

Rocuronium (Option D): Another non-depolarizing agent, commonly used for rapid sequence intubation. It does not cause malignant hyperthermia.

Key Takeaway:

Suxamethonium in combination with halothane can precipitate malignant hyperthermia in susceptible patients. Prompt recognition and immediate administration of dantrolene are critical to reduce mortality.

questions.text: What is the most effective way to verify the placement of the endotracheal tube in a 30-year-old male patient who has been intubated for surgery by a final-year resident?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most accurate and reliable method for confirming correct endotracheal tube placement is capnography, which measures end-tidal CO₂ concentration.
  • Continuous detection of CO₂ in exhaled air confirms that the tube is in the trachea and not the esophagus.
  • This method provides immediate, real-time, and continuous monitoring, making it the gold standard during anesthesia and resuscitation.

Malposition of the endotracheal tube can cause life-threatening complications, including hypoxia, esophageal intubation, or unilateral ventilation. Clinical methods alone are not sufficient; hence capnography is essential.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

X-ray chest (Option A): Helpful for confirming tube depth and detecting complications (eg, pneumothorax) but not practical for immediate confirmation at the bedside.

Auscultation (Option B): Checking for bilateral breath sounds is useful but unreliable, as air entry may still be heard with esophageal intubation or if the tube is inserted into one bronchus.

Chest rise (Option D): Visible rise of the chest does not rule out esophageal intubation, as bag-mask ventilation can also cause chest movement. It is only a supportive sign, not definitive.

Key Takeaway:

End-tidal CO₂ monitoring (capnography) is the gold standard for confirming endotracheal tube placement. While clinical signs like auscultation and chest rise are helpful, they cannot reliably exclude esophageal intubation.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image used for patients with COVID-19 infection.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is commonly used in COVID-19 patients who require high concentrations of oxygen while minimizing aerosol spread.
  • It delivers 60-90% oxygen through a reservoir bag and one-way valves that prevent rebreathing of exhaled gases.
  • By limiting re-inhalation of carbon dioxide and reducing aerosol dispersion, it becomes especially suitable in infectious respiratory illnesses such as COVID-19.

Non-rebreathing mask:

  • Components: Face mask, reservoir bag, one-way valves.
  • Oxygen delivery range: 10-15 L/min flow rate.
  • Indications: Severe hypoxemia, acute respiratory distress, and pre-oxygenation prior to intubation.
  • Advantages: Provides high FiO₂, prevents rebreathing, and reduces aerosol generation compared to nebulizers.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Venturi mask (Option A): Provides a fixed oxygen concentration (24-50%) and is typically used in COPD patients who require controlled FiO₂ to avoid CO₂ retention. It is not suitable for severe COVID-19 hypoxemia requiring high-flow oxygen.

Hudson mask (Option B): A simple face mask that delivers 40-60% oxygen but lacks a reservoir bag. It cannot deliver as high FiO2 as NRBM and offers less protection against aerosol spread.

Nebulizer (Option C): Used for aerosolized drug delivery. In COVID-19 patients, nebulizers increase the risk of aerosol generation and viral transmission, making them unsafe for oxygen therapy in this setting.

Key Takeaway:

For COVID-19 patients with significant oxygen demand, the non-rebreathing mask is the preferred choice because it delivers a high concentration of oxygen while minimizing the risk of aerosol generation.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most used nerve for monitoring?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neuromuscular monitoring is routinely used in anesthesia to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and recovery.
  • The ulnar nerve is the most widely used because it is easily accessible, reliable, and produces a consistent muscle response.
  • Stimulation of the ulnar nerve results in contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle, producing thumb adduction, which is easily observed and quantified.
  • This makes it ideal for evaluating both the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the adequacy of recovery before extubation.

Neuromuscular monitoring:

  • Typically done with peripheral nerve stimulators using train-of-four (TOF), tetanus, or double-burst stimulation.
  • It helps avoid residual paralysis and ensures safe recovery from anesthesia.
  • Adductor pollicis monitoring reflects conditions at the laryngeal muscles and diaphragm reasonably well, though these muscles recover earlier than peripheral ones.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Median nerve (Option B): Stimulating the median nerve causes thumb flexion, but this response is less reliable and less commonly used in routine neuromuscular monitoring.

Radial nerve (Option C): Innervates wrist and finger extensors. These responses are not standardized for neuromuscular monitoring, making it less suitable.

Metacarpal nerve (Option D): This nerve is not used for neuromuscular monitoring, as it does not consistently produce a reliable muscle contraction for assessing blockade.

Key Takeaway:

The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve in neuromuscular monitoring, with the adductor pollicis muscle contraction serving as a reliable marker for assessing depth of blockade and adequacy of recovery under anesthesia.

questions.text: Which fluid is administered most commonly during intraoperative blood loss?
questions.solution:
• Crystalloids are the most widely used intraoperative fluids for replacement during minor and moderate surgical blood loss.
  • They are inexpensive, readily available, and effective at maintaining intravascular volume.
  • Ringer's lactate (Hartmann's solution) is the most common choice as it closely matches plasma osmolality and electrolyte composition.
  • Although larger volumes are needed compared to colloids (approx. 3:1 rule for blood loss replacement), their safety, cost-effectiveness, and availability make them the first-line option.

Pediatric & Burn Resuscitation Pearls

  • Modified Parkland Formula (burns):
  • TBSA% × Weight (kg) × 4 = mL in 24 hrs
    • ½ in first 8 hrs
    • ½ over next 16 hrs
  • Maintenance fluids in children:
    • First 10 kg → 100 mL/kg/24h
    • Next 10 kg → 50 mL/kg/24h
    • 20 kg → 20 mL/kg/24h

Isolyte P (Option A): Incorrect. It is a balanced crystalloid and can be used, but Ringer's lactate and normal saline are more commonly used worldwide due to wider availability and lower cost.

Blood (Option C): Incorrect. Reserved for severe blood loss and anemia. It is not the first-line choice for routine intraoperative replacement because of cost, limited supply, and risks of transfusion reactions.

Colloids (Option D): Incorrect. Although they expand plasma volume more effectively, they are used far less commonly due to high cost and risks (renal injury, anaphylaxis, coagulopathy).

questions.text: Which of the following airway devices delivers a precise FiO₂ of 24-60% regardless of the patient's breathing effort?
questions.solution:
The Venturi mask is a fixed-performance/high-flow device that delivers a precise oxygen concentration (FiO₂), independent of the patient's inspiratory flow or breathing effort.

  • It works by entraining a fixed amount of room air through different-sized jets, allowing delivery of a specific FiO₂ between 24-60%.
  • Flow rates typically range from 2-15 L/min, depending on the desired FiO₂.
  • It is especially useful in patients requiring controlled oxygen therapy, such as those with COPD, to prevent hypercapnia caused by excessive oxygen.


Learning Objective:

  • High-Flow Devices: High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC), Venturi mask
  • Low-Flow Devices: Nasal Prongs, Simple Face Mask, Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred agent for inhalational induction of anesthesia in children?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for pediatric anesthesia induction due to its rapid onset, smooth induction, and non-pungent odour, making it well-tolerated in children.


Explanation of Other Options:

Desflurane (Option B): Desflurane has a pungent odor and causes airway irritation, which makes it poorly tolerated by children during mask induction, although it provides a rapid onset and emergence.

Halothane (Option C): Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction but has a slower onset than sevoflurane and carries a rare risk of hepatotoxicity, making it less suitable today.

Isoflurane (Option D): Isoflurane is pungent and irritant to the airway, leading to poor acceptance in children, and its slower induction makes it unsuitable for mask induction in pediatric patients.

questions.text: The resistance of the tube shown below is primarily because of:
questions.solution:
The resistance to airflow (R) in an endotracheal tube is primarily determined by its diameter. According to Hagen-Poiseuille law, the resistance is:


Where:

  • rrr = radius of the tube
  • Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius, making diameter the most critical factor in determining resistance.
  • Resistance is also directly proportional to the length and viscosity, but these contribute less significantly than diameter.

ETT Size and Length Guidelines:


Additional Points:

  • The cuff of the ETT is positioned 3-4 cm above the carina and 2-2.5 cm below the glottis to prevent injury and ensure proper ventilation.
  • Murphy's eye: A side hole near the tip of the ETT that allows continued ventilation if the end of the tube abuts the tracheal wall.
  • Internal diameter is the standard way to describe ETT size because it determines airflow resistance and suitability for ventilation.

questions.text: Which neuromuscular blocking agent undergoes Hofmann elimination?
questions.solution:
Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, a chemical process in which the drug is spontaneously degraded at physiological pH and temperature. This elimination pathway is organ-independent, making atracurium suitable for patients with renal or hepatic impairment.

Although atracurium can be safely used in liver failure, caution is advised in renal failure because its metabolite laudanosine can accumulate, potentially increasing the risk of seizures. Cisatracurium, a related agent, has a lower risk of toxicity due to the absence of significant laudanosine production.


Explanation of Other Options:

Pancuronium, Rocuronium, and Vecuronium (Options A, B & C) are primarily metabolized by hepatic and renal pathways and do not undergo Hofmann elimination. Hence, these agents are less suitable for patients with organ dysfunction.

questions.text: How much oxygen is given to a term infant with respiratory distress during resuscitation?
questions.solution:
• The amount of oxygen given to a term infant with respiratory distress during resuscitation depends on the severity of the respiratory distress and the infant's oxygen saturation levels.
  • The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends starting resuscitation with a 21% to 30% oxygen concentration for the term and preterm infants (≥ 35 weeks' gestation), adjusting the concentration based on the infant's oxygen saturation levels.
  • The goal is to maintain the infant's oxygen saturation between 90% and 95%

50% (Option B), 70% (Option C), and 100% (Option D): These higher oxygen concentrations are not recommended as initial oxygen therapy during resuscitation of term infants because:

  • Higher oxygen concentrations can lead to oxidative stress.
  • They may cause tissue damage.
  • Current evidence supports starting with room air (21% oxygen) and titrating up as needed.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD is admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure and is placed on mechanical ventilation. The intensivist increases the Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) to improve oxygenation. Which of the following is a contraindication to increasing PEEP in this patient?
questions.solution:
Tension pneumothorax is a contraindication to PEEP because it can further increase intrathoracic pressure, worsen lung collapse, and impair venous return, potentially leading to cardiovascular collapse.

Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP)

  • PEEP is the positive pressure that remains in the alveoli at the end of exhalation, exceeding atmospheric pressure in mechanically ventilated patients. It can be set on the ventilator (extrinsic PEEP) or may occur as a complication (auto-PEEP).
  • Benefits of PEEP:
  • Reduces alveolar trauma.
  • Enhances oxygenation by recruiting closed alveoli, increasing gas exchange surface area.
  • Increases functional residual capacity, improving oxygenation between breaths.
  • Improves ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) matching.
  • Increases lung compliance.

questions.text: In the given capnograph, what does the Phase 2 denote?
questions.solution: In a normal capnograph, the marked area represents the alveolar plateau phase. This is the flat part of the capnograph, indicating constant exhalation of CO2.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient undergoing orthopedic surgery under general anaesthesia suddenly developed a rise in EtCO2, temperature, and also muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs leads to such complications?
questions.solution:
• The scenario describes malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic agents, including halothane. It is characterized by increased EtCO2, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity.
  • It is most commonly associated with succinylcholine.

Incorrect Options:

Propofol (A), Nitrous oxide (B), and Etomidate (C) are not associated with malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: In which of the following is the given position used?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows the sniffing position. It is used during intubation to align the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it easier to visualize the vocal cords and insert the endotracheal tube.

Incorrect Options:

Neurosurgery (Options A): The sniffing position is not a standard position for neurosurgical procedures. Neurosurgery typically requires positions like supine, prone, or sitting, depending on the surgical site.

NG tube insertion (Options C): For nasogastric (NG) tube insertion, the patient's head is usually flexed slightly, not placed in the sniffing position. The tube follows the natural curve of the nasopharynx into the esophagus.

Bougie Insertion (Option D) - A bougie is a guide used for difficult intubations, but the sniffing position is not exclusively used for bougie insertion. The bougie is used after an initial attempt at intubation, usually in cases of a difficult airway

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is scheduled for elective cardiac surgery. To reduce the risk of postoperative infections, which of the following antibiotics is the drug of choice for preoperative prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic commonly used for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. It works by inhibiting the growth and multiplication of bacteria that can cause surgical infections.


Penicillin G (Option A ): It isn't often used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis due to its limited spectrum of activity, which doesn't cover all potential infection-causing bacteria.

Erythromycin (Option B): It isn't commonly used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis because it's less effective than other antibiotics in preventing surgical infections.

Azithromycin (Option C): It isn't commonly used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis because it's ineffective against all bacteria that can cause surgical infections.

Reference:

https://www.choc.org/userfiles/AntibioticProphylaxisForSurgeryGuideline.pdf

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness?
questions.solution:
The drug commonly used postoperatively to reverse muscle weakness induced by a nicotinic receptor antagonist (such as a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent) is Neostigmine.

  • Neostigmine:
    • An acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
    • This facilitates the activation of nicotinic receptors, effectively reversing the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium, vecuronium) and restoring normal muscle function.
  • Neostigmine is often co-administered with an anticholinergic agent (e.g., glycopyrrolate or atropine) to counteract muscarinic side effects such as bradycardia and excessive salivation.
  • It is specifically effective against non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers and is not used for depolarizing agents like succinylcholine.

Physostigmine (option A): Although physostigmine is also a cholinesterase inhibitor, it primarily crosses the blood-brain barrier and is used to reverse central nervous system effects of anticholinergic toxicity. It is not routinely used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

Carbachol (option C) is a direct cholinergic agonist that mimics acetylcholine. It is used in ophthalmology (e.g., for glaucoma) but not for reversing the effects of muscle relaxants.

Succinylcholine (option D) is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker used to induce paralysis during short procedures. It is not used to reverse muscle relaxation and may even worsen weakness if given postoperatively.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5568091/

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used for?
questions.solution:
• Type of Circuit: The Jackson-Rees circuit is a modification of the Mapleson F system.
  • Patient Population: It is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia, particularly in infants and small children.


Cardiac anaesthesia (Option B): Incorrect because the Jackson-Rees circuit is mainly used in pediatrics, whereas cardiac anesthesia typically requires closed-circuit ventilation with controlled settings.

Neuro anaesthesia (Option C): Incorrect because neuroanesthesia patients require precise ventilation control, often achieved with mechanical ventilators.

Obstetric anaesthesia (Option D): Incorrect because obstetric anesthesia mainly involves spinal, epidural, or general anesthesia with different breathing circuits.

choices.text: Revascularisation procedure if patient develops ST elevation post resuscitation
Bring the body temperature down to below 32 degrees, therapeutic hypothermia if unresponsive

questions.text: Which of the following must be avoided in post cardiac arrest resuscitation care?
questions.solution:
• Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) is recommended between 32-36°C, but below 32°C is not advised due to potential risks like arrhythmias and coagulopathies.
  • Therapeutic hypothermia (TTM) should be maintained at 32-36°C for at least 24 hours in comatose patients after cardiac arrest to reduce neurological damage.
  • Excessive cooling (<32°C) increases complications such as bradycardia, electrolyte imbalances, and impaired coagulation.

Post-Cardiac Arrest Care

Post-cardiac arrest care focuses on stabilizing the patient, preventing secondary organ damage, and optimizing neurological outcomes. It includes hemodynamic management, targeted temperature management (TTM), oxygenation, and coronary intervention when indicated.


Maintain MAP over 65 (Option A): Correct because maintaining adequate perfusion pressure (MAP ≥ 65 mmHg) is essential to prevent organ hypoxia.

Maintain SpO₂ above 94% (Option B): Correct because post-resuscitation oxygenation should be between 94-98% to avoid both hypoxia and hyperoxia toxicity.

Revascularisation procedure if patient develops ST elevation post resuscitation (Option C): Correct because emergency PCI should be done in post-cardiac arrest patients with STEMI to improve survival.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4959439/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4780335/
  3. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5523091/

questions.text: Ambu aura 40 is an example of?
questions.solution:
• Ambu Aura 40 is a second-generation supraglottic airway device designed for improved airway protection and ventilation.
  • It includes a gastric drainage channel, which helps reduce the risk of aspiration, a key feature of second-generation devices.
  • Better sealing pressure compared to first-generation devices, allowing for effective positive pressure ventilation.
  • Commonly used in elective and emergency airway management.

Generations of Supraglottic Airways (SGAs)

Supraglottic airway devices are classified into generations based on their features. Higher generations offer improved airway protection and better ventilation control.


Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 1 (Option A): Incorrect because first-generation devices lack a gastric drainage tube, while Ambu Aura 40 has one.

Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 3 (Option C): Incorrect because third-generation SGAs have more advanced sealing and monitoring features, which Ambu Aura 40 lacks.

Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 4 (Option D): Incorrect because fourth-generation SGAs are not yet widely available, and Ambu Aura 40 does not belong to this category.

questions.text:
Steps of intubation sequence are:

a. Flexion of lower cervical spine and extension of Atlanto-occipital joint
b. Inflate cuff of endotracheal tube
c. Introduce a laryngoscope from the right side of mouth
d. Confirm the position of tube
questions.solution:
Steps of intubation:

  • Flexion of the lower cervical spine and extension of the atlanto-occipital joint. It is an optimal and ideal position for intubation (also called the Morning sniffing position).
  • If you are a right-handed person then you will hold the laryngoscope in your left hand and start entering from the right side of patient's mouth till you see the epiglottis, once the epiglottis is visible, push the epiglottis anteriorly in adults then vocal cords will be visible
  • After this place the endotracheal tube, then inflate it.
  • Cuff pressure should not exceed 25

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents is associated with the Robinhood phenomenon?
questions.solution:
• The Robinhood phenomenon (reverse cerebral steal) occurs when vasoconstriction in normally perfused cerebral areas redirects blood flow to ischemic regions where vessels are already maximally dilated.
  • Thiopentone sodium decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMRO2) and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • It induces cerebral vasoconstriction, which favors redistribution of blood toward ischemic tissue, producing the reverse steal effect.

Explanation of other options:

Ketamine (Option A): Causes cerebral vasodilation and increases CBF and ICP, which can worsen cerebral ischemia.

Propofol (Option B): Causes global reduction in CBF and CMRO2, but is not specifically associated with the reverse steal phenomenon.

Etomidate (Option C): Minimally affects CBF and ICP, not associated with Robinhood phenomenon.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone causes cerebral vasoconstriction and may lead to reverse steal
  • Ketamine increases CBF and ICP
  • The Robinhood phenomenon benefits ischemic brain areas

choices.text: Maximum inspiratory flow may exceed 30L/min during spontaneous breathing
Nasal cannulae significantly improve oxygenation even if the patient breathes through the mouth
A Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle
A Hudson mask is a fixed performance device

questions.text: A patient on the high dependency unit has pneumonia and is hypoxia on room air. When deciding which method of oxygen administration is appropriate, which of the following statements is FALSE?
questions.solution:
The false statement is Hudson mask is a fixed performance device

  • A Hudson mask (also known as a simple face mask) is a variable performance device.
  • FiO2 delivered depends on:
    • Oxygen flow rate (typically 5-10 L/min)
    • Patient's tidal volume and respiratory rate
    • Degree of room air entrainment
  • FiO2 is not consistent, typically ranges between 35% and 60%, and is not reliable for patients needing precise oxygen levels.

Explanation of other options:

Maximum inspiratory flow may exceed 30 L/min during spontaneous breathing.(option A)

  • In spontaneously breathing patients - especially those in respiratory distress - peak inspiratory flow rates can exceed 30-40 L/min, and may go up to 60 L/min or more.
  • This is clinically significant when choosing an oxygen delivery device, as low-flow devices may not meet inspiratory demand, leading to entrainment of room air and variable FiO2.

Nasal cannulae significantly improve oxygenation even if the patient breathes through the mouth.(option B):

Even in mouth breathers, oxygen delivered via nasal cannula improves oxygenation due to:

  • Oxygen reservoir effect in the nasopharynx.
  • Positive nasopharyngeal oxygen concentration, which gets entrained during inspiration.

A Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle (Option C):

  • Venturi masks work via the Venturi effect, a manifestation of the Bernoulli principle.
  • High-velocity oxygen through a narrow jet creates a pressure drop, entraining room air at a fixed ratio, ensuring a precise FiO2, making them fixed-performance devices.

Key takeaway:

The Hudson mask is a variable performance device, not fixed, because FiO2 varies with patient factors (RR, tidal volume).

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and weakness. A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows a rate of 42 beats per minute with complete dissociation of P waves from QRS complexes. What is the most likely jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform that will be seen?
questions.solution:
• In the above case, there is complete dissociation of P waves from QRS complex that suggests AV dissociation and Heart block.
  • Cannon A waves are caused by atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve, such as in complete heart block.
  • JVP- Pressure of the venous column of blood in the Right Internal Jugular Vein.

Different waves in JVP:

  • A wave produced by right atrial contraction.
  • The C wave is produced during the ventricular systole.
  • X wave represents the fall in right atrial pressure after a wave peak.
  • The wave represents venous return to the right column.
  • Y descent represents the opening of the tricuspid valve.
  • Elevated JVP (>4 cm above the sternal angle) with normal waveforms may reflect right heart failure and fluid overload.
  • Elevated JVP with absent waveforms may be caused by superior vena cava obstruction.
  • Elevated JVP with deep x and y descents may be seen with constrictive pericarditis.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Absent JVP(Option A): may be present in patients who are intravascularly depleted

Absent a waves(Option B): may be seen in atrial fibrillation

Large v waves(Option C) are a feature of tricuspid regurgitation

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of severe COPD and reduced exercise tolerance is posted for a short, elective transurethral procedure under general anesthesia. He has a baseline SpO2 of 91% on room air and mild CO2 retention on ABG. To minimize postoperative respiratory depression and ensure rapid recovery with early discharge, which inhalational agent, owing to its lowest blood-gas partition coefficient, would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Xenon possesses the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient (~0.115) among all inhaled anesthetics, resulting in extremely rapid onset and offset. This makes it ideal for patients with limited pulmonary reserve, like those with COPD, where minimizing anesthetic-induced respiratory depression and ensuring quick emergence are crucial for safety and discharge.

Explanation of other options:

Methoxyflurane (Option A): Extremely high solubility (~12); slow recovery and nephrotoxic-obsolete.

Desflurane (Option B): Fast acting with low solubility (~0.42) but slower than xenon; also an airway irritant.

Nitrous oxide (Option C): Faster than most agents (~0.47), but still slower than xenon.

Key Takeaways:

Xenon provides the fastest recovery due to its lowest solubility; ideal for COPD and short-duration surgeries.

questions.text: What is the ratio of breaths to chest compressions when performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation alone in an adult?
questions.solution:
Whether there are one or two rescuers, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breath for all persons is 30:2, i.e. 30 chest compressions for 2 breathing pauses, if no advanced airway is placed.


Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic medications should not be used in chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
• Pethidine (also known as meperidine) is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain management.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, pethidine should be avoided due to its active metabolite, normeperidine, which can accumulate and cause neurotoxicity.
  • Normeperidine can lead to central nervous system excitation, seizures, and other adverse effects, particularly in patients with impaired renal function.
  • Alternative opioids with shorter or no active metabolites, such as fentanyl or sufentanil, are preferred in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: What anaesthetic gas is in the blue conduit in OT?
questions.solution: Blue pipeline in OT delivers Nitrous Oxide

choices.text: Immediate administration of IV magnesium sulfate and calcium channel blocker
Hyperventilation with 100% oxygen and rapid cooling measures only
IV sodium bicarbonate 1-2 mEq/kg to correct metabolic acidosis
IV dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg bolus, repeated every 5-10 min to a maximum of 10 mg/kg

questions.text: A 24-year-old male undergoing emergency laparotomy develops a rapid rise in end-tidal CO2, tachycardia, generalized muscle rigidity, and a core temperature of 40 °C soon after induction with halothane and succinylcholine. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rapid IV dantrolene is the only specific therapy proven to reverse malignant hyperthermia (MH). Dantrolene directly inhibits RYR1-mediated calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, reversing the hypermetabolic crisis. Early administration halts the hypermetabolic crisis, lowers CO2 production, and reduces rigidity and hyperthermia.

  • Initial dose: 2.5 mg/kg IV, repeat every 5-10 min up to 10 mg/kg until symptoms subside.
  • Maintenance: 1 mg/kg IV every 4-6 h or 25 mg/kg/hr infusion for ≥24 h (longer if signs persist).
  • Supportive care includes discontinuing all volatile agents/succinylcholine, hyperventilation with 100% O2 ≥10 L/min, active cooling (stop at 38 °C), correction of metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate, treatment of hyperkalemia (glucose-insulin, bicarbonate, calcium if severe), and maintaining urine output >1-2 mL/kg/h with alkalinization to prevent myoglobinuric renal injury.
  • Complications of dantrolene: muscle weakness, phlebitis, GI upset, respiratory failure, hyperkalemia; administer through a large-bore IV line. Avoid calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem, nifedipine) with dantrolene because of risk of severe hyperkalemia and cardiovascular collapse.

Explanation of other options:

Magnesium sulfate and calcium channel blocker (Option A): Magnesium alone cannot terminate MH and calcium channel blockers given with dantrolene can precipitate fatal hyperkalemia.

Hyperventilation and cooling only (Option B): Supportive measures are essential but without dantrolene mortality remains high.

IV sodium bicarbonate (Option C): Corrects metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia but is adjunctive, not definitive.

Key Takeaways:

  • MH is triggered by volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals (commonly RYR1 mutation).
  • Hallmarks: sudden hypercarbia, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, rapidly rising temperature, metabolic/respiratory acidosis, ↑CK, myoglobinuria, hyperkalemia.
  • Dantrolene is the only drug that halts the crisis and prevents death.

choices.text: Administer intravenous 10% calcium gluconate followed by high-dose epinephrine boluses
Immediate intravenous bolus of 20% lipid emulsion at 1.5 mL/kg followed by infusion
Give intravenous magnesium sulfate 2 g and prepare for synchronized cardioversion
Rapid infusion of 0.75% bupivacaine to antagonize sodium channel blockade

questions.text: A 30-year-old parturient undergoing epidural analgesia for labor suddenly develops circumoral numbness, metallic taste, tinnitus, and agitation immediately after administration of a test dose of local anesthetic. Within minutes she progresses to generalized tonic-clonic seizures followed by hypotension and wide-complex ventricular tachycardia. Which of the following next steps is the most appropriate to both treat the acute cardiovascular toxicity and improve the chance of successful resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient shows classical progression of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) - early CNS excitatory signs (tinnitus, metallic taste, circumoral numbness, agitation, seizures) followed by cardiovascular collapse with ventricular tachyarrhythmia.

  • Intravenous 20% lipid emulsion therapy is the recommended first-line treatment for bupivacaine-induced LAST that is refractory to standard resuscitation. Lipid infusion acts as a "lipid sink", binding lipophilic local anesthetics, particularly highly protein-bound and lipid-soluble agents like bupivacaine, and improves cardiac conduction and contractility.
  • Recommended dose: 5 mL/kg IV bolus over 1 minute, followed by 0.25 mL/kg/min infusion, with repeat bolus if cardiovascular stability is not restored.
  • If CV stability is not restored, repeat the 1.5 mL/kg bolus up to two additional times and increase infusion to 5 mL/kg/min. Do not exceed ~10 mL/kg in the first 30 minutes.
  • Supportive care includes airway management, 100% oxygen, benzodiazepines or propofol for seizures, and cautious use of vasopressors (preferably small doses of epinephrine ≤1 mcg/kg).
  • In LAST-modified ACLS, use small-dose epinephrine (≤1 mcg/kg); avoid vasopressin, lidocaine, and procainamide; amiodarone is preferred for refractory ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Bupivacaine is especially cardiotoxic due to slow dissociation from cardiac Na+ channels and is more likely to cause refractory ventricular arrhythmias compared to lidocaine or ropivacaine.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Risk factors: High vascular injection site (e.g., intercostal block), pregnancy, acidosis, hypoxemia.
  • CNS signs: Circumoral numbness → tinnitus → metallic taste → agitation → seizures → coma/respiratory arrest.
  • Cardiac signs: Initially tachycardia/hypertension (from CNS excitation or epinephrine admixture) → conduction delay, ventricular arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest.
  • Prevention: Calculate maximum safe dose; aspirate before injection; incremental dosing (“every dose is a test dose”); use epinephrine-containing test dose to detect intravascular injection.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium gluconate with high-dose epinephrine (Option A): Useful for hyperkalemia or calcium channel toxicity, not for sodium channel blockade of LAST. High-dose epinephrine worsens arrhythmias and is not recommended.

Magnesium sulfate and cardioversion (Option C): Appropriate for torsades or specific ventricular arrhythmias but does not address the underlying lipophilic toxin.

Rapid infusion of 0.75% bupivacaine (Option D): Would worsen toxicity; bupivacaine is the causative agent and has the highest risk of refractory cardiac arrest among local anesthetics.

Key Takeaways:

  • LAST is a life-threatening emergency. Early CNS warning signs must be recognized.
  • 20% lipid emulsion therapy is the cornerstone of management for severe cardiovascular toxicity, especially with bupivacaine.
  • Prevention includes meticulous technique and adherence to maximum dose recommendations.

choices.text: William Morton's public demonstration of diethyl ether

questions.text: The world anesthesia day is celebrated on October 16, this signifies
questions.solution:
• World Anesthesia Day (also known as Ether Day) is celebrated on October 16 every year. This day marks a historic public demonstration of surgical anesthesia by Dr. William T.G. Morton, an American dentist, who successfully administered diethyl ether to a patient undergoing surgical excision of a neck tumor at Massachusetts General Hospital in 1846.
  • This event is considered a major breakthrough in the history of medicine because it was the first successful public demonstration of surgical anesthesia, showing that surgery could be performed without pain.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: First use of chloroform
    • Chloroform was introduced as an anesthetic after ether.
    • Date: November 4, 1847
    • By: Dr. James Young Simpson, a Scottish obstetrician
    • He experimented with various chemicals for painless childbirth and found chloroform effective.
  • Option C: Discovery of Nitrous Oxide
    • Nitrous oxide (N2O) was discovered by Joseph Priestley in 1772, and its euphoric effects were later explored by Humphry Davy.
    • Horace Wells, a dentist, used nitrous oxide in 1844 for tooth extraction.
    • However, his public demonstration failed, so it did not lead to widespread adoption at that time.
  • Option D: First spinal anesthesia
    • Date: August 16, 1898
    • By: Dr. August Bier, a German surgeon
    • He performed the first documented spinal anesthetic using cocaine.
